We require a tools.jar of 1.4 since we are now supporting HotSwap. The JDI API 
from earlier does not include the hot swap support, and thus, the error. Do you 
need the tools.jar? We ship our own JDI library (jdi.jar), but I assume it is 
later on the classpath.

I need tools.jar to be able to run the ant rmic task from inside Eclipse.
I've added tools.jar using both the append and prepend switches to 
bootclasspath and I get the same result. I simply cannot move to 1.4 yet. 
Wouldn't it be possible to check whether that method exists before calling it? 
In other words, make sure Eclipse still works with JDK 1.3, tools.jar included? 
Maybe disable hotswap if running an early JDK? Or give us a way to run rmic 
without the need to use the tools.jar workaround :-).

As a workaround can you place the "jdi.jar" on your path before the tools.jar? 
(in "org.eclipse.jdt.debug/jdi.jar")
Done that and it works OK. Thanks.
*** Bug 22611 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Fixed. I added the method JDIDebugPlugin#getJDIVersion() which returns the 
detected version number of the JDI interfaces. This is detected by 
performing Class.forName("VirtualMachine").getMethod("canRedefineClasses", 
new Class[0]");

If this call throws a NoSuchMethodException, the JDI version is set to 1.3. 
Otherwise, it's set to 1.4.

I opted for a version number instead of a boolean in case we need to add 
similar checks for future JDI versions.

Everywhere that our JDT Debug Model calls a JDI 1.4 method, I've made sure 
that we first check the JDI version. Unfortunately, Sun's online JPDA 
specification is bugged and it misses at least one new method 
Method.isObsolete().

This is something we're going to need to maintain as we move forward.

Please verify.
